content: you will need 150 yards 137 1 m of worsted weight yarn some countries call this 10ply weight 5 0 mm us 8 needles straight or circular yarn needle to weave in ends skill level easy techniques employed longtail & backwards loop cast-ons knit stitches slipped stitches binding off gauge 16 stitches & 28 row to 4 10 cm square in garter stitch begin pattern longtail cast on 36 backwards-loop cast on 2 38 stitches total work the following pattern row for about 22 61 cm or desired length to make cowl fit as given in schematic all row knit to last 2 stitches move the yarn to the front of the work slip the last two stitches purlwise when the cowl is long enough to be wrapped as shown in schematic below bind off all stitches knitwise break yarn leaving 24 61 cm tail this cowl was born out of necessity which can sometimes masquerade as laziness why make a 6 foot 1 8 m garter stitch finishing scarf when you can make a 2 foot 6 m one instead unforeseen fold so that bind-off edge is along the side of the edge above bonus this scarf won t fall off or catch on anything have just the cast-on as shown in schematic below and thread yarn tail 150 yards 137 1 m of luxury yarn or leftovers from a project onto needle and sew into place making sure to not catch any part you don t need to buy two more skeins for a full-length mega- of the i-cord stitches it will look ugly from the right side if you tedious scarf make this instead do weave in ends note because the two stitches at each edge are only knitted to block get thoroughly wet with warm water gently squeeze once they will form a lovely cord instead of the garter stitch in out excess and lay flat to dry the center this is called a knit-in i-cord edge and will keep the edges from flopping or stretching out from wear h bind
